Award.AwardTitle: Probing interfacial phase-change transport events in flow boiling on micro- and nanotextured surfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1403657

The ever-increasing generation of heat has become an impediment to advancements and the efficient operation of many electronics and energy applications, such as power and RF electronics, high-performance computers, solid-state lasers, and concentrated solar cells. The liquid-cooling process has been considered a remedy for the thermal management of these applications. The phase-change liquid-cooling process in microchannels, in particular, has received significant attention. A main focus of the scientific community for nearly two decades has been to enhance the boiling heat-transfer coefficient in microchannel heat sinks. However, a major obstacle has been the relatively limited understanding of transport characteristics, which is caused by difficulties related to diagnosing interfacial behavior in microchannels. Such knowledge is essential to advancing the science and technology of compact and high performance two-phase flow heat sinks. The objective of this study is to use a new measurement approach to understand the physics of different microscale heat transfer mechanisms involved in flow boiling in microchannels.

The objective of this research is to utilize a new measurement approach to understand the physics of different microscale heat transfer mechanisms involved in flow boiling in microchannels and to measure their relative contributions to the overall surface heat transfer. Advancing both scientific understanding and engineering practice in this field requires experimental capabilities for characterization of the underlying interfacial processes. Furthermore, transformative improvements in the control of phase change heat transfer may come from the development of new mechanistic models, with inspiration and validation from experimental techniques that can probe temperature and heat flux with sufficient sensitivity over the relevant length and time scales. The proposed approach involves a high-resolution measurement of the thermal field (temperature and heat flux) at the fluid-solid interface in microchannels. The unique aspect of the proposed measurement approach is the implementation of a composite wall with embedded micro-sensors that allow the surface heat flux to be determined. The thermal field measurements are synchronized with the high-speed imaging of bubbles as well as the thickness of the liquid film formed between the vapor and solid phases. The laser interferometry method is utilized in measuring the liquid film thickness. Experimental studies will be conducted to explain the mechanisms of heat transfer in flow boiling in microchannels, evaluate the accuracy of prominent mechanistic two-phase microchannel models, and understand the role of surface micro- and nanostructures on the interfacial transport events and flow boiling characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For nearly two decades, the microchannel flow boiling heat transfer process has been the subject of numerous studies to understand the physics of the process in order to better predict and enhance its performance. Despite the efforts, critical aspects of the process have remained largely unknown. The shortcomings stem from the complex coupling of mass, momentum, and energy transport occurring between different phases. In the absence of a microscopic description of the heat and mass transfer events, different and sometimes contradictory hypotheses regarding the mechanisms through which heat is transferred to the fluid have been proposed. Advancing both scientific understanding and engineering practice in this field requires new experimental tools for characterization of the underlying interfacial processes. In addition, transformative improvements in the control of phase change heat transfer may come from the development of new mechanistic models, with inspiration and validation from experimental techniques that can probe temperature and heat flux with sufficient sensitivity over the relevant length and time scales.

Under this project, a new measurement approach is utilized to resolve the thermal field at the solid-fluid interface with unprecedented spatial and temporal resolutions. Experimental results presented here provide new physical insight on the nature of heat transfer processes during bubble growth and flow through the microchannel. The study is enabled through development of a device with a composite heated wall that consists of a high thermal conductivity substrate coated by a thin layer of a low thermal conductivity material with embedded temperature sensors. This novel arrangement of materials and sensors enables calculation of the local heat flux with a spatial resolution of 20-65 μm and a temporal resolution of 50 μs. The device generates isolated bubbles from a 300 nm in diameter artificial cavity fabricated at the center of a pulsed function micro-heater. Analysis of the temperature and heat flux data along with synchronized images of the bubbles show that the microscale flow boiling has a cyclic behavior and comprises of four basic heat transfer mechanisms: (1) thin film evaporation, (2) transient heat conduction, (3) interline evaporation and (4) single-phase convection. Details of these heat transfer events including their time period of activation and corresponding local heat flux and heat transfer coefficient are extensively studied. It is also shown how this knowledge allows to relate the bubble growth and flow dynamics to the surface heat flux.

The test results are then utilized to evaluate the accuracy of the prominent heat transfer models. The analysis shows the shortcomings of extending theories based on the superimposed concept, originally presented for macrochannels, to flow boiling in microchannels. A comparison with the existing models suggests that the three-zone flow boiling model can only qualitatively describe the heat transfer events but fails to accurately predict the magnitude of the heat transfer mechanisms.

Finally, the physics of microscale flow boiling process on micro- and nano-structured surfaces is examined. Prior microchannel flow boiling studies have hypothesized that induced capillary pressure in nanowire-coated surfaces promotes dry spots' rewetting process and hence augments the flow boiling heat transfer. In this study, for the first time, the drying time scale during combined wicking-thin film evaporation process at micrometer wicking length scale is directly measured. It is shown that the physics governing heat transfer enhancement in flow boiling on textured surfaces can be explained by three unique parameters: the drying time scale (τd), the heating length scale (δH), and the ratio of the thin film evaporation region to the projected area (Ar). Then, through experiments and modeling, optimum texture size that maximizes flow boiling heat transfer on micro- and nano-textured surfaces is determined.

Broader Impact: Heat generation currently limits a number of technologies such as power electronics, radio-frequency components, and solid-state lasers. The knowledge produced under this project advances the development and deployment of these technologies.

Microchannels are also of significant interest to chemical engineers in their efforts to develop “lab-on-a-chip” technologies, compact chemical laboratories that allows them to perform a variety of chemical processes on a chip a few millimeters in diameter. Both the instrumentation techniques and the mechanistic understanding of flow boiling increases the toolset available to them in this rich, emerging field.

Under this project, three high school students were hosted in the laboratory as part of the Summer Science Training Program (SSTP) run by the University of Florida Center for Precollegiate Education and Training (CPET). SSTP is a seven-week summer program in which high school juniors and seniors come to UF to conduct research in a laboratory. In addition to the laboratory research, SSTP students attend daily lectures, a biweekly discussion seminar, and have regular social activities. This schedule immerses students in a research experience and gives them training that will allow them to be successful in science and engineering when they enter college.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2018
Modified by: Saeed Moghaddam

This schedule immerses students in a research experience and gives them training that will allow them to be successful in science and engineering when they enter college.
